title: How to Ask Anyone on a Date over the Phone

steps.title: Check that the person you're calling does not already have a boyfriend/girlfriend.
steps.content: Check that the person you're calling does not already have a boyfriend/girlfriend. Skip this step if the person you are calling is your boyfriend/girlfriend.

steps.title: Know what you are saying.
steps.content: Know what you are saying. More often than not, a person will call another without knowing what to say.If you are unprepared, then you could create an awkward silence. Avoid this by writing out what you're going to say and rehearsing. (See Tips.) Still act natural though!

steps.title: Be specific.
steps.content: Be specific. Asking a person out without knowing where to go will hurt you when the day comes and make you less confident. If it is a movie or a concert then mention the time as well.

steps.title: Act Casual.
steps.content: Act Casual. Start up a conversation first. Once you feel comfortable talking to the person, go ahead and start with your rehearsed conversation.

steps.title: Avoid the dreaded awkward silence.
steps.content: Avoid the dreaded awkward silence . If there is a silence longer than fifteen seconds *Don't count, of course*, then say "It's OK if you don't want to..." or "You don't have to tell me now."

steps.title: Accept rejection
steps.content: Accept rejection . If the person on the other side says no, but does want to go out with you some other time, try again! Tell the person that you understand. Don't get angry, rude or sullen. If they're not interested, keep your response really casual and chill. Say something like, "Oh, well, you know, I really value our friendship and I hope I haven't done anything to jeopardize that. And so let's just go back to being friends just like we were before." Or, "Oh, that's a bummer. Good chatting with you, though." [1] X Research source

steps.title: Say "Thank you"
steps.content: Say "Thank you" if he/she does say yes. Congratulations! You have just asked a person out over the phone.
